original_data.question: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 6-month history of mild episodic abdominal pain. The episodes occur every 1–2 months and last for a few hours. The pain is located in the epigastrium, radiates to his back, and is occasionally associated with mild nausea. His mother is concerned that his condition might be hereditary because his older sister was diagnosed with congenital heart disease. He is otherwise healthy and has met all developmental milestones. He is at the 75th percentile for height and the 65th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abdominal distention, guarding, or rebound tenderness. Which of the following congenital conditions would best explain this patient's symptoms?

model_response:
The incidence of congenital hyperophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) is approximately 1–3 cases per 1000 births. The condition is most commonly seen in first-born males between 3 and 6 weeks of age. The classic history is of nonbilious vomiting that becomes increasingly projectile over the course of several days to weeks. Eventually, the infant develops almost complete gastric outlet obstruction. The examination of the abdomen reveals a visible gastric peristalsis, and the mass is palpable in the epigastrium. The diagnosis is confirmed by ultrasound examination. Biliary cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary tree. They are usually identified by the presence of a mass in the right upper quadrant and are associated with other congenital anomalies in 30% of cases. Intestinal malrotation is a condition in which the intestines do not rotate into their normal position as they prolapse into the base of the umbilical cord. The result is that the cecum is located in the right upper quadrant and the duodenojejunal junction is to the left of the midline. The condition is often associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia and congenital heart disease. The classic clinical presentation is that of acute bilious vomiting in a neonate. The abdominal radiograph shows a "double bubble" sign, and the diagnosis is confirmed by upper gastrointestinal contrast study. Pancreas divisum is a congenital anomaly in which the pancreatic ducts fail to fuse. The majority of patients are asymptomatic, but a small percentage can present with abdominal pain and recurrent pancreatitis. The diagnosis is made by ERCP.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Female parents, human or animal.
Record and study of past events.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The upper central region of the abdomen between the costal margins and the subcostal plane.
Joined in some kind of relationship.

An unpleasant sensation in the stomach usually accompanied by the urge to vomit. Common causes are early pregnancy, sea and motion sickness, emotional stress, intense pain, food poisoning, and various enteroviruses.
Female parents, human or animal.
A state of being, such as a state of health.
Transmitted through genes from parents to offspring. (genome.gov)

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
Developmental abnormalities involving structures of the heart. These defects are present at birth but may be discovered later in life.
Having no significant health-related issues.
An important event in the progress, development, or history of something or in someone's life.
The vertical measurement or distance from the base to the top of an object; the vertical dimension of extension.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Swelling of the abdomen resulting from excessive food intake, malnutrition, liver disease, primary abdominal tumors, and tumors metastatic to the abdominal cavity.

Used with disease headings to indicate those conditions existing at, and usually before, birth. It excludes morphologic abnormalities and birth injuries, for which "abnormalities" and "injuries" are used.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
